title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
text: This hands on exercise will involve going through the ggplot packages of R and applying the principle of Layered Grammar of Graphics. By the end, I will be able to apply the essential graphical elements provided by ggplot2 to create elegant and yet functional statistical graphics.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
text:
The code chunk below uses p_load() of pacman package to check if tidyverse packages are installed in the computer, if they are, then they will be launched into R.

pacman::p_load(tidyverse)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
text:
Importing the data

exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")

Rows: 322 Columns: 7
‚îÄ‚îÄ Column specification ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
Delimiter: ","
chr (4): ID, CLASS, GENDER, RACE
dbl (3): ENGLISH, MATHS, SCIENCE

‚Ñπ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.

text: Welcome to ISSS608 Visual Analytics and Applications. In this website, you will find my coursework prepared for this course.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
text:
R Graphics vs.¬†ggplot

ggplot2R Graphics



ggplot(data=exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=10, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="black", 
                 fill="grey") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")







hist(exam_data$MATHS)







From the comparisons above, it is relatively simple to use R Graphics due to the smaller code chunk, but ggplot2 is recommended because it provides more flexibility in customizing the graphs.
Also, as pointed out by Hadley Wickham:
‚ÄúThe transferable skills from ggplot2 are not the idiosyncrasies of plotting syntax, but a powerful way of thinking about visualisation, as a way of mapping between variables and the visual properties of geometric objects that you can perceive.‚Äù

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
text:
Installing and launching R packages
The code chunk below uses p_load() of pacman package to check if tidyverse packages are installed in the computer, if they are, then they will be launched into R.

pacman::p_load(tidyverse)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
text:
A Layered Grammar of Graphics

A short description of each building block are as follows:

Data: The dataset being plotted.
Aesthetics take attributes of the data and use them to influence visual characteristics, such as position, colours, size, shape, or transparency.
Geometrics: The visual elements used for our data, such as point, bar or line.
Facets split the data into subsets to create multiple variations of the same graph (paneling, multiple plots).
Statistics, statiscal transformations that summarise data (e.g.¬†mean, confidence intervals).
Coordinate systems define the plane on which data are mapped on the graphic.
Themes modify all non-data components of a plot, such as main title, sub-title, y-aixs title, or legend background.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
section: Essential Grammatical Elements in ggplot2: data
text:
Essential Grammatical Elements in ggplot2: data
Calling the ggplot() function initializes a ggplot object and a blank canvas will appear. The data argument is used to definte the dataset for plotting.

ggplot(data=exam_data)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
section: Essential Grammatical Elements in ggplot2: Aesthetic mappings
text: Essential Grammatical Elements in ggplot2: Aesthetic mappings

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
text:
Geometric Objects: geom_bar

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
text:
Geometric Objects: geom_dotplot

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot(dotsize = 0.5)

Bin width defaults to 1/30 of the range of the data. Pick better value with
`binwidth`.





Be warned that the y scale is not very useful and is in fact misleading. The code chunk below performs the following two steps:

scale_y_continuous() is used to turn off the y-axis, and
binwidth argument is used to change the binwidth to 2.5.


ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot(binwidth=2.5,         
               dotsize = 0.5) +      
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,           
                     breaks = NULL)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
text:
Geometric Objects: geom_histogram()
The code chunk below creates a simple histogram of MATHS field value using the default bin of 30.

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram()

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
section: Modifying a geometric object by changing geom()
text:
Modifying a geometric object by changing geom()
The code chunk below adds 3 arguments to modify the geometric object:

bins: change the number of bins to 20,
fill: shade the histogram with light blue color, and
color: change the outline colour of the bars in black


ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20,            
                 color="black",      
                 fill="light blue")

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
section: Modifying a geometric object by changing aes()
text:
Modifying a geometric object by changing aes()
The code chunk below adds a subgroup by using the fill argument in aesthetic().

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           fill = GENDER)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 color="grey30")

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
text:
Geometric Objects: geom_density()
The code chunk below shows a smoothed version of the histogram by computing and plotting kernel density estimate, which is useful to show continuous data that comes from an underlying smooth distribution.

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_density()




Below, two kernel density lines are shown by using colour or fill arguments of aes()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS, 
           colour = GENDER)) +
  geom_density()

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
text:
Geometric Objects: geom_boxplot
The code chunk below shows the median, two hinges and two whiskers, and all ‚Äúoutlying‚Äù points individually.

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS,       
           x= GENDER)) +    
  geom_boxplot()




Notches are used in box plots to help visually assess whether the medians of distributions differ. If the notches do not overlap, this is evidence that the medians are different.

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot(notch=TRUE)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
text:
Geometric Objects: geom_violin
geom_violin is designed for creating violin plot. Violin plots are a way of comparing multiple data distributions. With a violin plot, it‚Äôs easier to compare several distributions since they‚Äôre placed side by side.

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_violin()

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
text:
Geometric Objects: geom_point()
The code chunk below plots a scatterplot.

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point()

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
text:
geom objects can be combined
The code chunk below plots the data points on the boxplots by using both geom_boxplot() and geom_point().

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +                    
  geom_point(position="jitter", 
             size = 0.5)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
text:
Working with stat()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot()

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
section: Working with stat - the stat_summary() method
text:
Working with stat - the stat_summary() method
The code chunk below adds mean values using stat_summary.

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun.y="mean",         
               colour ="red",        
               size=4)

Warning: The `fun.y` argument of `stat_summary()` is deprecated as of ggplot2 3.3.0.
‚Ñπ Please use the `fun` argument instead.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
section: Working with stat - the geom() method
text:
Working with stat - the geom() method
The code chunk below adds mean values using geom_() function.

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  geom_point(stat="summary",        
             fun.y="mean",           
             colour ="red",          
             size=4)

Warning in geom_point(stat = "summary", fun.y = "mean", colour = "red", :
Ignoring unknown parameters: `fun.y`


No summary function supplied, defaulting to `mean_se()`

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
section: Adding a best fit curve on a scatterplot?
text:
Adding a best fit curve on a scatterplot?
The scatterplot below shows the relationship of Maths and English grades of pupils. The interpretability of this graph can be improved by adding a best fit curve.


ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(size=0.5)

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
‚Ñπ Please use `linewidth` instead.


`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'





The default method used is loess, but it can be overridden as shown below.

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
text:
Working with facet_wrap()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20) +
    facet_wrap(~ CLASS)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
text:
facet_grid() function

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20) +
    facet_grid(~ CLASS)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
text:
Working with Coordinate

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar()




The code chunk below flips the horizontal bar chart into vertical bar chart by using coord_flip().

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip()

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
section: Changing the y- and x-axis range
text:
Changing the y- and x-axis range
The scatterplot generated by the code chunk below is slightly misleading because the y-aixs and x-axis range are not equal.

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, size=0.5)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'





The code chunk below fixed both the y-axis and x-axis range from 0-100.

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics - ggplot2 methods
text:
Working with theme

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_gray()





ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_classic()





ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal()

title: In-class Exercise 1: Now You See It!
text:
In this in-class exercise, two R packages will be used. They are:

tidyverse, and
haven

The code chunk used is as follows:

pacman::p_load(tidyverse, haven)

title: In-class Exercise 1: Now You See It!
text:
In this in-class exercise, two R packages will be used. They are:

tidyverse, and
haven

The code chunk used is as follows:

pacman::p_load(tidyverse, haven)

title: In-class Exercise 1: Now You See It!
text:
Importing PISA data
The code chunk below uses read_sas() of haven to import PISA data into R environment.

stu_qqq <- read_sas("data/cy08msp_stu_qqq.sas7bdat")


stu_qqq_SG <- stu_qqq %>%
  filter(CNT == "SGP")


write_rds(stu_qqq_SG,
          "data/stu_qqq_SG.rds")


stu_qqq_SG <-
  read_rds("data/stu_qqq_SG.rds")
